description: From Middle French aphorisme, from Late Latin aphorismus, from Ancient Greek ἀφορισμός (aphorismós, “pithy phrase containing a general truth”), from ἀφορίζω (aphorízō, “I define, mark off or determine”), from ἀπό (apó, “off”) + ὁρίζω (horízō, “I divide, bound”), from ὅρος (hóros, “boundary”).

entries.meaning: A concise, terse, laconic, or memorable expression of a general truth or principle.

verbs.description: aphorism (third-person singular simple present aphorisms, present participle aphorisming, simple past and past participle aphorismed)
